Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>>I see no need to test methods other than public <snip> I'll write 
>>
> 
>  > test methods for the protected methods as well.
> 
> So why do you test protected methods if there's no need to test methods 
> other than public?  Simply because it depends.  Sometimes you want to 
> test protected methods, sometimes you don't.
> 
> My point is: placing tests classes so that it is _impossible_ to test 
> protected methods is a "bad" decision because you restrict your 
> flexibility.  By placing test classes in the same package, you still 
> have that flexibility, but you don't have to use it if you don't want to.

Well said. Here's my own phrasing of it... even if *in general* you only 
test the public interface, there will be times when public bugs are 
caused by protected/private methods. In that case, you want to write 
unit tests for the protected methods, in order to isolate the problem 
from the complexities and potential side effects of the public 
interface. If you put your test classes off where they *can't* test 
protected methods, then you have prevented yourself from using JUnit to 
test protected methods *ever*. What's the benefit of that? Intellectual 
purity? Falling back on seat-of-the-pants debugging?

Putting test classes with the main classes to enable testing protected 
methods does not *require* that protected methods be tested. Putting 
them in a separate package, however, makes it impossible (or at least 
possible only through a public interface redirection kludge).
